DataElement.preferredName: Disease or Disorder New Malignant Neoplasm Pre-existing Malignant Neoplasm Attribution Scale
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the relation of causality between the pre-existing malignancy and the specific new malignancy.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Disease or Disorder New Malignant Neoplasm Pre-existing Malignant Neoplasm Attribution
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to a new (not seen before) malignant neoplasm (a tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues) and the attribution (to assign to a cause or source) to a pre-existing (having been present before a specific date or event) malignant neoplasm.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A definite pathologic process with a characteristic set of signs and symptoms. It may affect the whole body or any of its parts, and its etiology, pathology, and prognosis may be known or unknown.

Concepts.definition: Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.

Property.preferredName: New Malignant Neoplasm Pre-existing Malignant Neoplasm Attribution
Property.preferredDefinition: Having no previous example or precedent or parallel; of a kind not seen before.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:Having been present before a specific date or event.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:assigning to a cause or source.

Concepts.definition: Having no previous example or precedent or parallel; of a kind not seen before.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
Having been present before a specific date or event.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
To assign to a cause or source.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: scale of values to indicate the causal relation between the treatment modality and the specific adverse event.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A subjective answer of very strong agreement.

Concepts.definition: A subjective answer of very strong agreement.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A measure of the expectation of the occurrence of a particular event.

Concepts.definition: A measure of the expectation of the occurrence of a particular event.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having little chance of being the case or of coming about.

Concepts.definition: Having little chance of being the case or of coming about.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not connected or associated e.g. by kinship.

Concepts.definition: Not connected or associated e.g. by kinship.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition:
any unfavorable symptoms, signs, or disease temporally associated with the use of a medical
treatment or procedure that may or may not be considered related to the medical
treatment or procedure.

Concepts.definition: An ordered reference standard used to measure incremental changes.
